channel.title: Patrioscript
channel.description:
A series of 13 patriotic plays by professional freelance writers as edited and directed by Herbert Prescott with the Grinnell College Radio Players.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Watermelon
item.description: "Watermelon," by Don Anderson. Is it "all a publicity stunt for that pipsqueak radio station...or is watermelon for a sick boy important enough to send a pilot a thousand miles through the rain?
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Courage '53
item.description: "Courage '53," by Jack Foss. This is an exciting play which seeks the answer to the question: "Where do men find the courage to fight a war?"
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Educated schoolhouse
item.description: "The Educated Schoolhouse," by Francisca Emerson Brown.
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Great-Grandfather was an immigrant
item.description: "Great-Grandfather was an Immigrant," by Herman Salinger. Meet Great-Grandfather Dorfer, the man who conquered America and let it conquer him as well.
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: Theater & Drama

item.title: Conquered, the unconquerable, and I
item.description: "The Conquered, the Unconquerable, and I", by Mary Agnes Thompson. An Icelandic person and a Polish person visit the United States, finding both strengths and weaknesses.
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Young Doc Smith died tomorrow
item.description: "Young Doc Smith Died Tomorrow," by Mary Agnes Thompson. The Grinnell College Radio Players call this a truly great play, epitomizing the words of a great American: "Only courage and sacrifice can keep freedom alive..."
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Republic of the blind
item.description: "The Republic of the Blind," by Gerald Cullinan. It was foggy that night. Not the usual kind of fog, either. Yet out of that fog came as strange a group of characters as you are likely to meet.
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Grand jury
item.description: "Grand Jury," by Bessie F. Collins highlights the virtues and challenges of jury duty.
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: Theater & Drama

item.title: Prejudice unlimited
item.description: "Prejudice Unlimited," by Bruce F. Anderson is an examination of a man who hates anyone that isn't like him.
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: Theater & Drama

item.title: Coat of many colors
item.description: "A Coat of Many Colors," by Mary Agnes Thompson. what is patriotism, anyway? Follow Nancy as the rides the busses, meets the man on the campus, and woman in the crowd, as she seeks the answer.
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Blueprint, U.S.A.
item.description: "Blueprint, U.S.A.", by Jack V. Porter. You will "be there" in this production featuring man-on-the-street coverage of the Constitutional Convention of 1787.
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: United States--History--18th century

item.title: Guided tour
item.description: "Guided Tour," by Bernice McMahon. You are invited on a tour of historic Gettysburg, when you will meet a young boy who has no trouble seeing and talking with characters who others don't believe are in the play at all.
item.dc:creator: Prescott, Herbert
item.dc:subject: Travel & Leisure
